The Constitution of India

The Constitution of India is the supreme law of India. It lays down the framework defining fundamental political principles, establishes the structure, procedures, powers, and duties of government institutions, and sets out fundamental rights, directive principles, and the duties of citizens.

It is the longest written constitution of any sovereign country in the world. Dr. B.R. Ambedkar is regarded as its chief architect. The constitution was adopted by the Constituent Assembly on 26 November 1949 and came into effect on 26 January 1950.

Constitutional Chronicle

26th January 1950

Constitution Comes Into Force

The Constitution of India was adopted by the Constituent Assembly on 26th November 1949 and came into effect on 26th January 1950, marking India's transition to becoming a sovereign democratic republic.

Did You Know?

The original Constitution was handwritten in both English and Hindi. The calligraphy was done by Prem Behari Narain Raizada.

Latest Update

104th Constitutional Amendment

Extended the reservation of seats for SCs and STs in the Lok Sabha and state assemblies by 10 years (until 2030) and removed the reserved seats for Anglo-Indians.
